page.title: 11AMBLE HARBOUR
page.content: In{1835 Radcliffe Colliery was opened. With it came the demand for a harbour to{export the coal.}In{1837}Parliament agreed to the building of a harbour at {Pan Haven,}which cost{Â£180,000}and took over{ten years}to build. North and south{piers }were erected eighty yards apart, but the north pier needed {constant attention}because it had been {constructed of sandstone}which easily weathered.{Radcliffe Colliery}bought the harbour and then later it was taken over by{Broomhill Colliery Co. A{railway line}was built to the harbour and{staithes}were erected for the transfer of the coal to the ships. Amble developed as a{port}as the {demand for coal grew,}and the town was the{centre of the region.}However, in the second half of the{20th century when the{mines closed,}the harbour {declined}except for the{fishing trade.
